text: Hello everyone. I'm Stephen Phillips.
I'm a solution architect here at Epic.
So I'm uh a mix between technical
support, technical sales, making sure
that um customers on the architecture
side can use Epic tools like Unreal
Engine, Twin Motion, Reality Capture,
and all the other fun things we do. Uh
but today I'm just talking about Twin
Motion mostly and how it applies to
everything across the Ako ecosystem. So
I there's familiar faces in this room um
from multiple areas of it. Um, but I'm
curious, you know, is anyone here not in
AECO?
Okay, that's fine. That's good. I cut
just a couple. And then, um, is everyone
here mostly know Twin Motion and how it
works? Are there any people who are a
little beginner? Okay, so a couple
beginners. Good. We're going to cover,
um, a lot of scattered things here. The
agenda is deceptively simple. I'm just
going to go through the AECO which is
you know really roughly chronological
order of the life cycle of you know ACO
project. Um and throughout we're going
to cover a lot of different use cases
some tips and tricks um features you
probably use and probably don't know
about uh here and there. So for my goals
I hope I can remind you of some features
that have been there for a long time
that have been forgotten or not promoted
in 5 years. uh educate you on new

more exciting and ideally can inspire

maybe you can use Twin Motion on more

use it more wisely.
So, you know, across the four main
industry segments we're covering, I'm
going to make some really broad
generalizations. I'm going to
oversimplify your job roles so I
apologize for that. Um but when it comes
to, you know, how Ako works with 3D
software, there's like a 90% overlap. So
um all of you can use all of these tools
that we're going to talk about. We're
going to start with A for architecture.
Uh so roughly speaking this is you know
the design of buildings. Um because it's
part of the initial design phase. Um
there's kind of a broad spectrum of
visual uh targets. So maybe it's so
early in the in the design that you want
a more stylized non-photoreal look so
that you're not distracting people with
the wrong things. Or maybe you need it
to look really amazing because you're
trying to sell the dream and win the
project.
Um, so we have Datasmith plugins for
just about every major CAD software like
Revit, Rhino, SketchUp. Um, like this is
our old friend, the sample project from
Revit. And Twin Motion has a great
relationship with these guys. So in Twin
Motion, when you go to import a file,
not only do you get BIM files through
the geometry tab, but in that direct
link tab, it'll actually see Revit and
you can establish a link there. So, this
is the direct link uh streaming in that
Revit model to Twin Motion really
quickly, which is really great if you're
going to be using your dcc software side
by side with Twin Motion and making
constant changes and pushing those
updates. Once it's inside Twin Motion,
whether it's the file import or the
direct link, you can always send your
Twin Motion project somewhere else like
you can give it to external people or
internal people and they don't have to
have access to your Revit um work. Once
you're inside Twin Motion, um, we have a
huge library, like I think tens of
thousands of assets from things that
we've 3D modeled just for, you know, AEC
projects. Um, there's animated
characters in there. There's direct
access to the Quickixle assets,
including a ton of 3D plants that
technically aren't in that foliage
category. And then there's Sketch Fab
assets, too. So, that's over 700,000
community-made models that are free to
use for commercial use. And it's all
inside this content browser. You don't
have to go to fab. You don't have to
download stuff uh purchase things uh at
all actually for inside motion.
There's these really simple path tools
to add some life, some animation to the
scene. So with just a couple clicks, you
can have pedestrians walking out the
sidewalk. There's a few different
categories of um what outfits they're
going to wear um like Middle Eastern
outfits, travel, beach.
Then you got the same tool for bicycle
lanes um filling it up with people
riding their bikes. So you can make it
um really fast people or really slow
bicyclists.
And the same thing for vehicles as well.
So in literally three clicks we can have
a lane a road full of moving vehicles uh
with one lane or up to I haven't tried
past four lanes on each side but um you
can go pretty far with that.
And similarly, the ambiance system is
super easy to use inside Twin Motion. So
trees are smart assets that can grow and
change with the different seasons. Time
of day is just a really quick slider,
and it's geographically accurate if you
set your location.
Volutric clouds are a pretty cool new
feature. So, um, these are true 3D
clouds that can move and transform, and
you get lots of parameters to change and
animate inside of your content.
And then we have like seasonality and
weather too. So you can make it snow if
you want. You can make it rain uh and
all the different materials react
appropriately. And then for true
seasonality, the trees are also going to
react like this. And deciduous trees are
going to, you know, change leaf colors
and drop their foliage and grow it back
in the springtime. And you you can hook
all that up to have every camera angle
with a different season or have videos
that animate between any of these
parameters.
Um there's a couple useful tools. So,
there's a measurement tool built into
Twin Motion. Um, there's actually a new
one called measure tool 2, and you can
click two points and get a really quick
measurement to verify your roads the
right size, your doorway is the right
size. There's also a checkbox um called
constraint. So, this will shoot the
measurement ray out from the surface.
That's really handy for like measuring
the interior of a of a room and seeing
how far across the walls are without
trying to go and click and and get get
the right spot perfectly.
On the rendering side, um, Tune Motion
looks pretty good by default, but you
can enable this clay render. So, this
will be your stylized layer. You can
just replace all the materials in the
scene with a solid color. And you get
some options for excluding things like
foliage and characters, uh, vehicles.
Unfortunately, at this moment, I don't
think there's a way to exclude exactly
your imported model. Um, so if you
needed to do that, you would just be
assigning or making a configuration just
for the material replacement on
everything else.
So all of that adds up to like you know
what feels like a living breathing view
of your architectural projects that you
can update as the designs get updated
and u really quickly create different
renders and different scenes.
On the camera side um lesser known than
the regular camera is orthographic
features. So this is not found under the
the camera tab of the ambience. It's
actually in the top right corner of the
viewport. There's a little eye icon and
when you go to the 3D house icon that
controls, you know, top down, left,
right, orthographic projection, and the
thing on the bottom right is actually a
custom angle. So, you can move that
orthographic camera wherever you want
and um clip through the scene and get
these perfectly straight lines, which
looks really, really cool. And it works
with all the animated features and
everything else. It also works really
well with our um section cube. So, this
is a a feature in Twin Motion where you
can just drag out a box and cut through
any walls and any any geometry. So here
you can like slice away the exterior
wall and then use one of those
orthographic cameras to get a really
cool elevation floor plan. And it all
works really well with the path tracer
too. So you can you can really push the
quality or enable one of our other like
stylized outline effects.
There are a lot of export options for
Twin Motion. Um and you can do them all
at once if you want to. So, of course,
there are still renders, um, video
animations that are really simple to
create, 360 panoramas, which if you've
ever tried to make those in Unreal
Engine, it's like way easier than
Unreal. Um, this stuff is is so smooth.
And then you can also export your whole
Twin Motion file as a presenter
executable. So, this would be like um
someone downloading your file without
the editable capabilities and having all
the animations there to walk around and
look at from every single angle. And
that works with like a mouse and
keyboard setup or virtual reality as
well. And for the executable um and the
360 panoramas, we also offer for people
who pay for their Twin Motion seats uh
the cloud presenter and cloud panorama
sets. So you can actually just send
somebody a URL and they can access your
project really really fast without you
um sending a multi- gig file and hoping
they have the right hardware for that.
Um I wanted to show you the VR mode
inside of Twin Motion. So, if you prefer
to look at your projects in that spatial
um situation and navigate them like
that, it's like a three-click operation
to do that from Twin Motion. I want to
take the opportunity though to point out
quality and performance options here. I
think by default, we leave VR quality at
like ultra and but if your scene is only
running at 45 frames per second in Twin
Motion, it is not going to run at 45
frames per second in VR and it's going
to be a really not great experience for
your end users. So, make sure you go
into your preferences and in the quality
tab, there's a a second VR tab where you
can um change quality levels. So, I
recommend going to medium and
potentially even low because Twin Motion
focuses on like great lighting, lots of
dynamic objects, you know, dynamic
shadows. Those things are really
impactful to VR. So, you should be just
expecting to to turn off some of those
features to have a really smooth,
comfortable experience. And um on the
content side, object count is going to
be a big one. So either removing objects
or using the new modeling tool to merge
objects together. Um and turning off
lights and turning off dynamic shadows
if you can afford it.
Moving on to the engineering category.
Um for engineers there tends to be a
little bit more external data like maybe
you're running different analyses um in
other software and you know making sure
the building is going to actually
structurally stay in one piece.
uh there's also the chance for these to
be bigger scale projects because you
know if you're developing a huge
interstate freeway then that falls under
engineering and related to that this
also means that if if you're going to be
affecting people's commutes or affecting
environmental um areas then you need to
be able to communicate your projects um
from this engineering standpoint too.
So this scene has a really basic office
interior um but perhaps there are some
engineers who are working on things
behind the walls. So, this was a chance
for me to remind you guys that we have
this cool X-ray mode. It's actually
built into every material in Twin
Motion, and it's just a little checkbox
to turn on. And anything that has that
mode is rendered on top of the rest of
the scene. So, you could have different
colors. You could have blue and red
objects for like hot and cold, air or
water, or electrical things could be
yellow. And it's a good um showcase for
the configurator tool as well because
maybe you don't want it to look like
that at all times. So configurations are
a new media type that you can create and
you can choose from different types.
This one would be a properties
configurator and best practice of course
is to always name your configurations
and name your configuration states. So
this is like the default no X-ray mode
of the scene and then I just go to the
material of my MEP work and I turn on
X-ray. go back to that media
configurator and just make a new state.
And I name it, you know, X-ray on. And
now Twin Motion has this little button
for me that I can click on to toggle
X-ray on and off for all these uh MEP
meshes. And you can mix and match lots
of configuration states. And you can
make it that 2D widget or um you know
add a custom icon to it. So it's a
really clever way to introduce more
interactivity and more ways to present
your content. On the large project side,
I wanted to come up with an example
here. So, this is a terrain that I
actually imported um into Unreal and
exported and it was made using the Cinta
Fab plugin. Um so, it's a free uh
resource to access real terrain data and
I draped over some USGS imagery on top
to make it a little higher resolution.
Um so, Twin Motion benefits from the
same technology that Unreal provides um
under the hood. So you have the large
world coordinates, you have double
precision, so you can handle really
physically large worlds. There's a
slight limitation on the camera speed
kind of reaches a max. So if you need to
jump, you know, a mile down the road,
then you probably want to have a little
object in the scene graph that you can
click on and hit the F key to jump over
there. And of course, we'd love the road
to be filled with cars. So I did um here
I'm dragging out the little spline to
put cars along the couple miles worth of
road. And it does work, but I want to be
transparent that once you end up with
hundreds or thousands of Twin Motion
vehicles, your scene tends to slow down
a bit because every car is looking for
the ground surface and every car is
steering its wheels tends to be a little
bit complex for that scale uh and high
frame rate. So, if that's okay enough,
then uh you can just turn off the cars
if and when you need them or just deal
with a lower count of cars. And if you
really want um a lot of traffic data in
Twin Motion, I have an idea that I'm
going to present later at the end of the
section.
Another kind of data that I think people
forget about in Twin Motion is point
clouds. So I wanted to do an example of
this. There's a tool from the USGS
called the LAR Explorer and it has like
I don't know how many terabytes of data
but um the entire country of the United
States basically has this aerial LAR

public. So I downloaded one of these
sections and the slide is not broken. It
really is black when I look at it in
cloud compare. Uh you can see the little
lake in the top left corner though. Um
but inside the list of scalar fields
like all the data channels of the LAR
point cloud is this other one called
number of returns. So this would be the
when the LAR point bounces around the
world and then returns up to the sensor
that gets recorded and it's a cool way
to find like foliage or edges of
buildings. So you could replace you
could modify the LAR data and like
project satellite imagery on top of it
in something like cloud compare but I
thought this was a good enough example.
And this is that data set just directly
inside of Twin Motion. I split it up
into a couple pieces, three pieces, but
it's still 1 and a half by 3 km wide, 63
million points, and it's a pretty cool
way to just fly around this 3D LAR data
in real time. We give you the option to
replace the color with like a solid
color of your choosing. um you won't be
able to do any other complex management
of the point clouds like you would in
software dedicated to that. But um if
you have your color data baked into that
first main channel of the point cloud
then it looks it looks really cool in
Twin Motion.
I wanted to explore um kind of an

So for construction, um scheduling
matters a lot. You know, you're going to
be working on a building now for five
plus years. You got to make sure it's on
time, on budget. Got to make sure people
know what's going to happen at different
phases of construction. There's also the
safety aspect, which is usually number
one at every firm. Um, you know, every
worker needs to be trained and to follow
the rules, follow the law. And
construction can also be dirty and
noisy, and you're going to be blocking
off roads. So, you want to be able to
communicate that with um internal,
external stakeholders, and even the
general public. So, this is just one
image of really quick Twin Motion scene
I put together using standard library
assets. Like, you can show people, hey,
this is what the road closure is going
to look like. You could put them into

around and make sure, you know,
pedestrians have the right access to the

So, back to my deck. Um, don't look too
closely at the design of it because I
think you'll have some critiques, but I
wanted to animate this and do some
construction phasing um to, you know,
maybe show my wife like what it's going
to look like when it's only halfway
complete during the summer picnic. But
in Twin Motion, there's a feature just
for phasing animations. It's um called
the phasing group. It gives you this
little calendar timeline where you can
key frame visibility of objects. So you
can turn off everything by default and
then um slide the calendar down to a
specific day, turn on a section, slide
the calendar, turn on a section. Really
easy to use tool to kind of build up
your scene. You can even incorporate
construction vehicles off to the side
and other things that are changing along
along this. And at the end, you get this
scrubable animation of the different
phases that you can incorporate into
individual media renders like videos
that actually show the animation coming
in and out. But it's a little limited in
that it's just visibility key frames. It
doesn't get too detailed and too fancy.
So, for my deck that I want to animate,
if we jump, uh, I want things to fall in
from the sky. I want things to be
animated and really sexy. I want the
deck top to like roll out from the side.
I want to get a little fancier than Twin
Motion allows. So, I only recently
learned from my colleague Simon Blakey
that you can actually export animated
sequences from Unreal Engine to Twin
Motion. And so, this is the only part of
the presentation where I'm going to go
like really technical, but um, you also
don't have to use Unreal for this if you
don't want to.
So, the first step is definitely always
making sure your projects are organized.
Um, I don't have like real 4D scheduling
for this makebelieve deck, but I have
different folders that I'm going to
organize into the different phases of
construction. And for every phase of
construction, I have an actor in the
scene that is an editor utility actor.
So, um, this actor contains a lot of
parameters. It has a list of all the
objects that I want to be animated as
part of the phase. And it has a
transform offset. So, if I want things
to drop from the sky, there's a relative
Z transform. If I want them to rotate
in, there's a relative rotation. And
then I have a a weight period and an
animation duration so that maybe the
whole phase of objects comes in at once.
Or maybe it staggers into a really fancy
effect.
And if you can't read that, don't worry.
It might not even work if you copy
pasted it. But I just wanted to
summarize um my method for procedurally
animating this in Unreal. If you've ever
done sequencer animation in Unreal, um
hopefully you found it somewhat simple.
You have your sequence, you drag your
mesh into the sequence, you click the
key frame on the transform track, and
you know that's your animation. If you
want to script it out, it actually gets
a little bit more complex, which I
learned the hard way. So, I just wanted
to clue you in if you wanted to do do
this yourself. First, you get the the
reference to the level sequence. Then,
you add a possessible for every object
that you're going to animate. And then
you add a track to the possessible which
would be a 3D scene transform track. And
you would think you just add the key
frame directly to the track. But
actually you need to add a section to
the track. And then in that section
there are multiple channels of
transforms. So you need to select like
you know location.z trans channel and
apply the key frame and then you're good
to go. So it was a lot more work but it
really pays off at scale. Um this is
what it ends up looking like when I just
batch create those key frames. So every
object here has a little offset with
just a couple transform key frames and
they can all slide into place and drop
around which is pretty cool.
To get that animation out of Unreal, um
you can the best method is to bring your
level sequence into the world as an
actor, select that actor and any
referenced meshes that it animated and
do a file export selected. You can also
just right click on the level sequence
in the content browser to export it. But
right now that will also export like
everything in the level um even if it
wasn't referenced. So um this is the
best method. And to get things from
Unreal Engine to Twin Motion, my
favorite format right now is GB. So
that's a glTF uh binary format. It's a
single file. It's lightweight. It embeds
all the textures. Uh it has support for
the level sequences and a few other
things. Unfortunately, the the one
downside is that it will bake your
textures, but for like a CAD model, it
doesn't matter. You're going to replace
it all in Unreal Engine anyways.
In Twin Motion, instead of importing
that GB as a as geometry, which you
could as for static stuff, you're going
to import it as an animation, and it
will read all those tracks and all those
key frames. We support transform tracks
for moving meshes around. We support
skeletal animation, so you can have
fully rigged deformable characters.
Those can also be imported. Now, we do
not support visibility tracks. So, if
you want something to appear out of thin
air and drop down, you have to set the
scale to zero, which sounds really
scary, but it works just fine. Uh, and
then we don't support any of the other
sequencer tracks, like, you know, um,
you're not going to be able to have
blueprint functions and material
parameters and camera cuts. Those stuff
are not going to be understood by Twin
Motion. So, this is the final uh, deck
animation.
This the structural beams fall into
place. And then we can lay out every

um direct the motion of the animation.
